reviewText: Dick Powell and Elizabeth Scott fail to bring this screenplay to life. Seems like a great premise for a thriller, the bored and boring married man getting himself into a mess of trouble from a short-lived affair with a young woman. However, it all feels mundane in this film  as the director seems too intent on proving the moral of the story that sexual indiscretion leads to disaster for post- war American middle class.

reviewText: At first you could say that Pitfall's main theme is the most politically and morally correct theme possible for a film shot in the late 40's. A married man is bored of his everyday-life, meets a sexy woman, cheats on his wife, feels terribly guilty about it, is punished by the Divine justice (which is totally in line with the Code Hays by the way) and finally implores his wife to take him back. Now, if I tell you that his mistress is NOT your typicable bad girl but feels sorry for the cheating husband, you'll understand why Pitfall is considered, by the rare ones who've seen this little pearl, as one of the best film noir ever released. Highly recommended.

reviewText: I tend to struggle with some films older film noirs, and I couldn't say why specifically.  I tend to believe that, with today's crime statistics, some of these older films present issues and portrayals of crime and violence that are almost quaint by contemporary standards.  So long as the performances are solid, I can almost sit through anything, though I prefer flicks where there's less emphasis on the philosophy of the circumstances and more emphasis on some quality acting, but I thought much of PITFALL felt uneven if not downright listless, not in a good way.(NOTE: the following review will contain minor spoilers necessary for the discussion of character and plot.  If you're the kind of reader who prefers reviews entirely spoiler-free, then I'd suggest you head elsewhere or scan down to the last two paragraphs for my final assessment.  But if you're the type who doesn't mind a few hints of things-to-come, then read on!)John Forbes (played by the reliable Dick Powell) is a man at a personal crossroads.  Sure, he loves his wife, Sue (Jane Wyatt), but he misses the welcome adventurousness from the early days of their marriage.  "Whatever happened to the two people who were going to buy that boat and sail around the world?" he wonders aloud, and she tells him that she got pregnant and he became a father.  Still, doubts persist for a path to a better life, and that's exactly when Mona Stevens (Lizabeth Scott) enters his life.  Down on her luck but awash in a life of luxury fueled by her boyfriend-turned-convict, Stevens has a boat; but Forbes - as the insurance inspector taxed with repossessing her ill-gotten gains - can't bring himself to take it away from her.  Smitten, he stumbles into a brief extra-marital affair, and this attracts the attention of J.B. MacDonald (Raymond Burr), the slumming private eye Forbes hired to look into Mona's personal affairs.  As fate (and any good noir script) would have it, MacDonald's also taken by the fashion model, and his desires force him to put Mona, Forbes, and the soon-to-be-released convict on a collision course toward brutality.PITFALL was directed by Andre de Toth with a script by Karl Kamb (based on the novel by Jay Dratler).  There's a great amount of banter between husband and wife - and later between lover and lover - that propel the strengths of the first half, but as the inevitable `pitfalls' develop much of that muscle vanishes in favor of brute strength.  Forbes and MacDonald exchange fists based on different circumstances, and both come out looking good and not-so-good alternately.  It's Burr, however, who pushes these players to the ultimate climax - hint: noirs NEVER end well for everyone involved - so the parts wherein he's removed from this volatile equation don't function as well as when he's present.Still, quite a bit of PITFALL hasn't aged as well as one would like.  In the end, it all comes off feeling a great deal like a pro-marriage message picture - not a bad thing, but there really was no TV avenue for Lifetime Movies in the early 1950's.  I'd imagine that a whole cadre of bible-thumpers would've recommended it as "standard viewing" for newlyweds before they consummated their nuptials as clearly the bulk of the resolution favors wedded bliss over casual copulation.  When everyone has something to prove, the union of man and wife won't work out as well as originally intended; while I personally agree with that message, I'm not all that convinced that PITFALL makes for a worthwhile presentation in the modern age.PITFALL is produced by Regal Films, and this DVD's distribution is being handled through Film Chest Media.  It looks and sounds about as well as any black & white shot in 1948 can for its full eighty-eight minutes, but, alas, there are no special features to speak of.  Shame, shame, shame!  There's the real crime, indeed!RECOMMENDED with some reservation.  PITFALL isn't entirely forgettable, but it's sure close for me.  I expected better of Dick Powell.  Anybody else?  So far as film noir goes, it's an interesting addition worth (at least) a single view, but I'd find it very hard to believe that any scholars or buffs would find it to hold up well on subsequent viewings.  While the story (infidelity, stalking, and some non-violent crime) remains timely, the performances don't, with Powell vacillating between weird male perkiness while exploring his unfaithfulness to a wooden, almost laughable stoicism when experiencing pangs of remorse over the same.  It goes without saying that Wyatt's porcelain good looks look downright magical here, so how was any red-blooded male supposed to accept Lizabeth Scott's raspy vixen as a convincing substitute?  To his credit, Burr looks menacing just standing there, rounding out the lead players.In the interests of fairness, I'm pleased to disclose that the fine folks at Film Chest provided me with a DVD screener of PITFALL by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review.
summary: It's A Perfectly Competent (Though Dated) PITFALL

reviewText: The film has some interesting acting, especially by the two lead women and Burr, but the story pace is plodding and the main character Forbes is in a bad mood for almost the entire film -- which makes the film drag almost as if it is in slow motion.  The heavy moralizing is typical for the time, but seems as heartless in the end as the heartless insurance man in the beginning.  So watch it for the acting, but the story pace and minor film noir elements bump this movie out of a true classic rating.

reviewText: Unlike most noirs, this isn't fundamentally a crime story, although there is a murder in the mix. It's about a decent man (Dick Powell in his noir period) with a great family and a good job who slips almost accidentally into an affair with the wrongest possible woman (the definitive femme fatale Lizabeth Scott). The real pressure comes from Powell's fear of losing his marriage, and that's all the more suspenseful because it's so possible.

reviewText: This movie strikingly reveals character and the moral consequences of flawed human choices.The pacing of the film is well-oriented to an audience's expectations without being predictable and without any sluggishness.At first, I thought the heavy consequences of a brief love encounter was over-the-top, until the end when the film makes clear there were other, better and moral decisions, other better and moral actions, the lead figures might have taken.Lizabeth Scott can be annoying in some of her noir films, but here she plays an innocent and her lisp isn't on display.Dick Powell's portrayal of the average husband with a brief mood disorder is completely on target.Raymond Burr is excellent as the bad guy.

reviewText: One of the all time great Noire films.  Lizabeth Scott is one of the all time sexiest with the sultry voice that just kills. She does a fantastic job as the beauty just trying to make her way in this topsy turvy world.  Dick Powell is perfect as the stand up guy who stumbles.  Jane Wyatt is rock solid as the rock solid wife.  But the real treat here is Raymond Burr.  He plays the consummate creepy scumbag. This is the true dark character of the film, and the acting is good enough to be truly disturbing.  Maybe because Burr's character takes me a little by surprise, but this might be his best performance.  Very enjoyable.  Great writing.  Good lighting.  I watched it via stream, and the picture was good, and the sound quality decent for a movie of this age.  If you care about this genre, a must watch.
summary: All time great Noire -With an all time great Raymond Burr

Then he makes mistake after mistake. Raymond Burr plays the heavy and you can hardly wait to see him get his, knowing poor Liz will be hurt. The best you can say is you do not want to play around as you will get hurt in some way. I do not believe many people have learned anything.

reviewText: I love film noir movies with Lizabeth Scott. She's the perfect noir seductress--sassy, blonde, hot and with a heart as cold as liquid nitrogen at subzero. She was great at portraying conniving "dames" who lured men to their ruin and her role as Mona, the model girlfriend of a convicted thief in "Pitfall" is one of her best roles. Mona is genuinely charming and likeable, and it's no wonder Dick Powell's character John falls for her after just one boat ride. Raymond Burr is wonderfully creepy as police detective Mack who also wants Mona, and wants Powell out of the way so he can have her. Ironically, she shoots him in the end, so neither man gets her. Jane Wyatt was also very convincing as the put-upon housewife whose life is ruined by John's affair with Mona. A great noir classic. Scott is not quite as icy and seductive as in my favorite of hers, Byron Haskin's brilliantly written "Too Late for Tears," but she's still one of the best noir "femme fatales."

reviewText: I must say that I love black and white movies. There is something dramatic and primal in a film that relies on facial expressions and verbal delivery to capture the viewer. Having said that I can add that I am a big fan of mystery and murder plots add to the fascination . Movies made during that era often involve people making stupid choices and then lying to support those choices. I can never understand why they don't just tell the truth. I also like the villains. Their selfishness is unbelievable, particularly the role played by  Raymond Burr. This guy was no Perry Mason. There was not even a hint of such a character. My overall reaction was this was an excellent movie.

reviewText: Now here is a serious noir film! The cast features Dick Powell, Jane Wyatt, Raymond Burr and Lizabeth Scott. Powell is an L.A. insurance man, slowly becoming bored with his predictable suburban lifestyle. His wife is Jane Wyatt, the perfect 40s/50s homemaker. Trouble brews when Powell hires a smarmy P.I. (Burr) to investigate a theft of property. This is long before his role of Perry Mason.  Burr gets the perpetrator  (Byron Barr) arrested.  Powell visits Barr s girlfriend to wrap things up and reclaim the remaining goods. But this is no ordinary lady! This is the classic noir good girl/bad girl-Lizabeth Scott. The two have the requisite noir affair, even though Barr is her supposed boyfriend! The plot thickener is that P.I. Burr also is interested in Scott, leaving the 3 male leads pining for the same girl! The by now obvious villain, Burr, visits boyfriend Barr in the slammer, teasing him with tales of Powell and Scott. Matters intensify more when Burr pays Barr's bail and gets him drunk enough to try to kill Powell. Good girl Scott phones Powell to warn him. In the deadly showdown, Powell kills the boyfriend. LAPD presses no charges. This reviewer won t reveal the resolution of The Pitfall but at this point Burr and Scott are still standing. Most viewers may side with Scott but fate does not exactly smile on either.  There is one more dead body and one more live one on the way to San Quentin. The film fades out after Powell has confessed all to the wife. She stands by him in the true 40s/50s tradition but allows that things will never be the same again. One doesn t know who to feel sorriest for, the dead characters, the one on the way to the Big House or Powell-who will have to face his wife every morning for the rest of his life while still trapped in his hum drum middle class life. While working at an insurance company, no less! A staple of noir films is the essentially good but basically weak human caught in a maelstrom set in place by others more devious than (s)he. That is an apt capsule description of  Pitfall and it has an excellent film wrapped around it. It may be short of those murky night shots, dark streets and strange camera angles of other noir classics.  Pitfall remains a wonderful 40s/50s showcase, with a large dab of middle class malaise tossed in- all in a run time of 86 minutes! Highly recommended!

reviewText: I've been a fan of noir from adolesence and have seen many such films--this isn't any where near that catagory in my opinion. There is nor double crossing femme fatale or business partner in the truest sense of the noir genre. Dick Powell, not one of my favorites----is ok here. Elizabeth Scott, one of my favorites---has been better.  In my opinion the most entertaining is Raymond Burr---also one of my favorites. I grew up on Perry Mason not realizing for many years that he had a film career prior----usually playing the heavy. Since I have made it a point to see as many of his previous works as I can each time being thoroughly entertained.In short this is an ok film, but if you are looking for noir I recommend Out of the Past, The File on Thelma Jordan, Gilda or Double Indemnity to name a few.

reviewText: Great noir from a great director of noirs ( Crime Wave ) and westerns ( Day of the Outlaw ) Andre de Toth. Other reviews have discussed the plot which takes the usual theme of married man falling for another woman and causing havoc because of the dalliance.What stood out to me in this movie was the high level of performance de Toth got from a great cast, Jane Wyatt in the normally thankless role of the good wife, Dick Powell as the bored husband, Liz Scott as the other woman, and in the best performance in the movie Raymond Burr as a psycho stalker channeling Lars Kreager from I Wake Up Screaming.This IS a masterpiece that had me rivited for the entire length of the film.....highest recommendation.
summary: Off beat film noir from de Toth

The plot had a certain amount of originality for a change.Finally, it helped introduce Raymond Burr as a heavy, and he couldn't have been much nastier.I wouldn't exactly call this one a masterpiece, but worth watching nonetheless.

reviewText: So I guess, if you've been in the war and been a good husband for a while, you get one hall pass and one get out of jail free card? Even a noir had to have a Hollywood ending, I suppose.Didn't it feel like Lizabeth was trying to channel Becky Bacall?  With the platinum hair helmet and low sultry voice, I know Dick is supposed to fall for her but I just didn't buy it.  We know Burr is a slimeball right from his first scene, but Smiley wasn't such a catch either was he?  This was not a woman with great taste in men.Speaking of passes, isn't it interesting that she will need to pay for HER sin of killing slimeball Burr, but Powell won't be held accountable for killing the BF of his one-night stand.  Or did they stand?  Again in the '40s, we're only shown that it's 11:30 at night and Powell is done for the evening and ready to head home, we'll never really know what did or didn't happen in her love shack with the revolving door.The biggest problem here is, of course, there's another film noir about someone in the insurance business in LA that just blows everything else out of the water.
summary: Only if you've seen it - spoilers

reviewText: "Pitfall" is the bleak, beautiful tragedy of a man who makes one mistake, and watches his life spiral out of control as a consequence. I'll forgo a plot synopsis (earlier reviewers have that covered) and merely note that the print-on-demand Synergy Entertainment DVD is a lousy transfer of a terrific movie. The image on this disc is faded and slightly blurred from beginning to end -- for viewers of a certain age, it's like catching this picture, with uncertain reception, on a local TV station's late, late show (back when there were things on late night TV besides infomercials). The sound, though, seems fine.In the absence of any other available DVD transfers of this movie, this disc will do. It'll have to.

reviewText: A very interesting movie that doesn't really fit into any genre.  Most films now days don't involve the viewer as far as realistic character identification.  Pitfall gives you the father of the family that lives next door....the Joe Everyman and then draws you in deeper and deeper identifying with this character and the decisions he makes.  The film steers away from stereotypes and creates complexities and continues to carry the central character lower and lower into the pitfall until near the end an elevator attendant is calling out to this character "Down, down" which is no mistake in the script.  This film has a brilliant dialogue script well worth listening to in detail if one wants to know how to put a movie together and the casting and acting are first rate.  The kid steals it with some of his lines and Raymond Burr somehow manages to completely capture the creepiest character you will ever see in the movies.  A real subtle artist's touch applied to every aspect of this film and since the film sucks you in as it should by getting you involved with BEING the central character, there's a good chance that you'll be emotionally drained by the end.  Great character study as far as how people end up the way they do in this life and it shows how one little misstep can send one into a pitfall.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Although she appeared in over twenty films before her career was abruptly halted because of rumors surrounding her lesbian private life, Lizabeth  Scott is best remembered for her steamy roles in noir films.  Scott hits  the mark in the 1948 picture Pitfall as Mona Stevens, a seductive siren who  charms a conservative insurance investigator ( Dick Powell) into an affair.  Powell as John Forbes, the married suburbanite bored with the restricting  bonds of middle class conformity, is drawn into a web of deception that  begins when he alters an insurance report benefitting  Mona. Forbes then  begins an affair with Mona.  The affair for Forbes serves as a sexual  escape from his regimented life as husband, father, and loyal employee.  For Mona, the affair might bring her happiness as a future wife and mother.  Mona only has convict Bill Smiley ( Byron Barr) to wait for as his parole  date draws near.  To compound her problems, a psychotic, overweight,  private investigator ( Raymond Burr) is  stalking her.  Forbes and Mona's  lives cross for a brief interlude, but the events that emerge as a result  of  their dalliance shape into classic noir cinema.  Deception, revenge,  murder-all frequent vistors to the frames of noir, appear as lessons to  those that dare play with fire.  Pitfall is a solid film that warrants  attention.
summary: Excellent Title For A Fine Film

reviewText: This film noir is better than I expected.  Powell's wife is played by the wife in "Father Knows Best."  As bored insurance salesman, Powell looks for a little excitement in his life and finds it in a woman implicated in an insurance fraud case.  He falls for her more out boredom than love.  Yet, he pays a terrible price for this little indiscretion.  Near the end of the film, it is a little implausible that he didn't seek police protection which would have saved him a lot of grief.  Yet, the film still works.  It is entertaining and a good story.
